newsitem.title: HONG KONG: S&P says Thailand has no competitiveness problem.
newsitem.headline: S&P says Thailand has no competitiveness problem.

text.p: Standard and Poor's Corp believes that Thailand has no fundamental problem in its export competitiveness, S&P said in a conference call on Friday.
S&P also said it expects Thailand's exports to start to pick up later this year.
"Thailand does not have a fundamental export competitiveness problem," said Cem Karacadag, S&P sovereign analyst in New York.
He said that while Thailand has lost some edge in lower value-added exports, it is making strides in the shift toward higher value-added goods.
Because of the economy's openness and flexibility, it can respond to competitive challenges, Karacadag said.
"Usually at this time in an economic cycle we would start to see signs on an export pick-up and we are starting to see evidence of that in Thailand," he said.
"Thailand is well-placed for its export sector to pick up in the second half of 1997 and into 1998," he said.
S&P expects Thailand's current account deficit to shrink to five percent of gross domestic product by next year, a forecast it deemed conservative.
The rating agency also expects Thailand's gross domestic product to grow roughly 5.0 percent in 1997 and in 1998 after an estimated growth rate of 6.7 percent in 1996.
S&P affirmed Thailand's sovereign ratings and stable outlook last month. S&P rates Thailand's long-term foreign currency debt at Single-A and its long-term local currency debt at AA.

S&P reiterated in the conference call held earlier today that it does not believe that the troubles plaguing Thailand's financial sector will adversely affect the country's long-term sovereign rating because the problems are manageable.
